THE LISTENERS HIP OF THE RESIDENTS OF ATHENS, OHIO
to
THE OHIO UNIVERSITY RADIO STATION 1956-57
INTRODUCTION
The problem of educational radio in providing a maximum broadcasting
service with limited funds has been the subject for much research# Radio
educators continue to examine the relative cost and advantages of AM, FM,
and Wired Wireless as a means of serving their audience*
Ohio university entered the broadcast scene in 19^2 with the establish¬
ment of a "wired-wireless” radio station# The coverage of this station was
not too successful* Surveys related to transmission and reception of the
radio signal indicated that only a portion of the student audience could
receive the signal#
To solve this reception problem, the University authorized the addition
of a 10 watt FM radio transmitter, on December 12, 19^9, at a cost of
approximately $5,000# This method of transmission did not seem to help
the reception problem# A survey of the appliance dealers in Athens showed
that about 750 FM sets were located in the area, and it was assumed that
some of these set owners listened to WOUN-FM (the university call letters
at that time)# Students continued to listen to the inadequate ”wired-
wireless” type of transmission# Students, it seemed, either did not havs
FM receivers, or did not choose to tune these sets to FM radio#
